history.content:
I would highly recommend the MacBook Pro line for iOS dev. If you don't want to purchase the newest version, the apple refurbished store (https://www.apple.com/shop/refurbished/mac) has some pretty good deals. I believe that students qualify for up to 200 dollars off a new one through apple if you use their education store (https://www.apple.com/us-hed/shop).

Unfortunately a Windows/Linux machine isn't really an option for native iOS dev. If you can find a used 2015 Pro model, that is the one I have and I love it. I've had it for a little over 3 years now and it works the same as it was when new. I do iOS dev almost every day and I have no complaints :) 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If I'm understanding correctly, you might also want to look into this. I have a 2012 MacBook Pro and had this issue over the summer. 

https://beetstech.com/blog/prevent-a1278-mid-2012-hard-drive-cable-failure

I would highly recommend the MacBook Pro line for iOS dev. If you don't want to purchase the newest version, the apple refurbished store (https://www.apple.com/shop/refurbished/mac) has some pretty good deals. I believe that students qualify for up to 200 dollars off a new one through apple if you use their education store (https://www.apple.com/us-hed/shop).

Unfortunately a Windows/Linux machine isn't really an option for native iOS dev. If you can find a used 2015 Pro model, that is the one I have and I love it. I've had it for a little over 3 years now and it works the same as it was when new. I do iOS dev almost every day and I have no complaints :) 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I had the EXACT same issue. Turns out it wasn't a hard drive issue but rather a hard drive cable issue. Hopefully that helps with your decision. 

https://beetstech.com/blog/prevent-a1278-mid-2012-hard-drive-cable-failure

I would highly recommend the MacBook Pro line for iOS dev. If you don't want to purchase the newest version, the apple refurbished store (https://www.apple.com/shop/refurbished/mac) has some pretty good deals. I believe that students qualify for up to 200 dollars off a new one through apple if you use their education store (https://www.apple.com/us-hed/shop).

Unfortunately a Windows/Linux machine isn't really an option for native iOS dev. If you can find a used 2015 Pro model, that is the one I have and I love it. I've had it for a little over 3 years now and it works the same as it was when new. I do iOS dev almost every day and I have no complaints :)

children.subject: ~Also, 100% get an SSD in the next computer you get~
(the 2015 one is the last one available in 15 inch which does not have a touch bar)

> If you can find a used 2015 Pro model, that is the one I have and I love it.

10x this! :) Don't get the touch bar, extra price for nothing really. The keyboard's a mess on some of the newer models as well...

You can save some more money by opting for a late 2015 model that doesn't have a dedicated graphics card. If you can, look for one with a 2.5 or 2.7 GHz processor with 16GB memory, although the memory might be harder to come by. I've got the MJLT2LL/A (paid $1400 on ebay / apple care for a year) connected to an external display because my desktop is out for the count, and it's handling multiple Xcode workspaces, browser tabs, and a postgresql server.

I haven't had any issues with mine yet, but that could change quick :D

Searching by the model # is a good way to get exactly what you want on sites like ebay, and you can strip off some of the last characters (like the "/A" part) to match more models.

I think more people should really consider buying from people on Facebook Marketplace and Craigslist (with a little precaution of course). I've bought unopened Surface Books and MacBook Pros within 6 months of their release at bigger discounts than available at any retailer, nothing was shady. (barely used ones are also sold on said sites)
I'd recommend waiting for the 2019 MacBook Pro release since it's rumored to improve the keyboard.

history.content:
I think my hard drive died last night.

Was working fine in Soda Hall, took it back to my house, then it showed a white screen with a question mark. Tried fixing it, my Macintosh HD wasn't even an option to select, which has been indicated as potential dead hard drive. I'll go to the Apple store in a few days, but i'm considering buying a new laptop. Mine is a Macbook Pro 2012 model, and was decently fine for google searches and email, but incredibly slow for programming. It would take over 30 minutes just to create a simulator in Xcode. I plan to work as an iOS dev, and would like to build projects on my free time.

Any recommended computers? I saw the new Macbook Pros are $1800 :( so expensive..

I also want a laptop that tends to last long. If I do end up paying a lot, I don't want it to die within a few years.
history.subject: Good laptop for iOS Dev, Decent Speed, and General Programming?
